facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 101 to 104 of 1957 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals-. Nos. 101 to 104 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeals arose from Mysore High Court judgment and order dated February 4, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated February 4, 1954, of the Mysore High Court in Regular, Second Appeals Nos. 5 and 6 of 1953 and Writ Petitions Nos. 67 and 68 of 1953 respectively.

facts.text: State of Mysore passed the first Mysore Act (No. XLVII of 1949) on July 7, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On July 7, 1949, the then State of Mysore passed The Mysore Administration of Evacuee Property Emergency Act, No. XLVII of 1949 hereinafter called the first Mysore Act .

facts.text: Custodian issued notification on September 21, 1949, declaring properties of the two respondents as evacuee properties vested in him.

anchor.surface_text: On September 21, 1949, the Custodian issued a notification by which he declared the properties. of the two respondents as evacuee properties which had vested in him,

facts.text: Two respondents filed claims under s. 8 of the first Mysore Act.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon two claims were filed under s. 8 of the first Mysore Act separately by the two respondents.

facts.text: Second Mysore Act (No. LXXIV of 1949) came into force on November 29, 1949, repealing the first Mysore Act.

anchor.surface_text: This Act remained in force till it was replaced by the Mysore Administration of Evacuee Property Second Emergency Act, No. LXXIV of 1949 hereinafter called the second Mysore Act , which came into force on November 29, 1949.

facts.text: Deputy Custodian dismissed the claims on April 17, 1950, declaring properties as evacuee properties.

anchor.surface_text: These claims were investigated by the Deputy Custodian who dismissed the same on April 17, 1950, declaring that the, properties were evacuee properties.

facts.text: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 came into force on April 17, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, No. XXXI of 1950 hereinafter called the Act , came into force on the day the Deputy Custodian passed the order dated April 17, 1950.

facts.text: Custodian allowed appeals on August 22, 1950, holding insufficient evidence to prove respondents as evacuees.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals were allowed on August 22, 1950. The Custodian held that there was number sufficient evidence to prove the respondents as evacuees and consequently the properties in question companyld number be treated as evacuee properties.

facts.text: Custodian-General issued notices on October 3, 1950 under s.27 of the Act to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: On October 3,1950, the Custodian General gave numberices to the respondents under s. 27 of the Act in respect of the order of the Custodian dated August 22, 1950,

facts.text: Administration of Evacuee Property Amendment Act, No. LXVI of 1950 passed on December 7, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On December 7, 1950, the Administration of Evacuee Property Amendment Act, No. LXVI of 1950, was passed by which inter alia s. 58 of the Act was amended

facts.text: Custodian-General set aside August 22, 1950 order on February 11, 1952 and remanded for fresh disposal.

anchor.surface_text: On February 11, 1952, the Custodian-General set aside the order of the Custodian dated August 22, 1950, and ordered that further proceedings in these cases should be taken before the Custodian as an original matter

facts.text: Custodian directed Deputy Custodian on April 7, 1952 to record evidence.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter thus came back to the Custodian he ordered the Deputy Custodian on April 7, 1952, to record the evidence and then submit the record to him for final disposal.

facts.text: Custodian held on December 2, 1952 that respondents were evacuees and properties were evacuee properties.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually, the matter came before the Custodian for final disposal on December 2, 1952. He held that the two respondents were evacuees and their properties were evacuee properties.

facts.text: Two appeals filed to High Court on January 2, 1953 against December 2, 1952 order.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by two appeals to the High Court on January 2, 1953.

facts.text: Two writ petitions filed on September 7, 1953 against Custodian's order.

anchor.surface_text: As, however, the respondents felt some doubt whether any appeal lay to the High Court two writ petitions were also filed on September 7, 1953, against the order of the Custodian.

facts.text: Mysore High Court disposed of appeals and writ petitions by common judgment on February 4, 1954, allowing them and restoring August 22, 1950 order.

anchor.surface_text: The two appeals as well as the two writ petitions were disposed of by the High Court by a common judgment on February 4, 1954. The High Court held that the appeals before it were competent.

facts.text: Mysore High Court granted certificates for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon followed applications by the Custodian of Evacuee Property, Mysore, for certificates to file appeals to this Court on which the High Court-granted the certificates,

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment on February 20, 1961, allowing the appeals and restoring Custodian's order of December 2, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeals, set aside the order of the High Court and restore that of the Custodian dated December 2, 1952.

facts.text: Custodian-General had jurisdiction under s.27 of the Act to revise the order of August 22, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that considering the purpose for which the Act was passed and the successive saving clauses in the second Mysore Act and in the Act,,the Custodian General had the power under s. 27

facts.text: No appeal lay to High Court from Custodian's order of December 2, 1952 under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was in error in holding that appeals to it lay from the order of December 2, 1952.

facts.text: High Court lacked jurisdiction to interfere via writ of certiorari with Custodian's December 2, 1952 order on merits.

anchor.surface_text: In the view we have taken, the order of the Custodian-General was with jurisdiction and therefore there was in our opinion numberreason for the High Court interfere in the exercise of its jurisdiction under Art. 226

facts.text: Proceedings commenced under s.8 of first Mysore Act were deemed under subsequent Acts to be under equivalent provisions.

anchor.surface_text: As we have pointed out above the proceedings under s. 8 of the first Mysore Act are in substance equal to proceedings under s. 5 of the second Mysore Act

facts.text: Second Mysore Act repealed by the Act from April 17, 1950 via retrospective amendment.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear therefore that the second Mysore Act was expressly repealed as from April 17, 1950, by the Act in view of this substituted s. 58 put into it retrospectively by Act LXVI

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the High Court could not deal with the matter before it as if it were hearing an appeal it could only consider the writ petitions before it and in doing so it would not be justified in issuing a writ of certiorari against the order of December 2, 1952, because that order was not passed without jurisdiction and there was no error of law apparent on the face of the record to call for interference with it.

holdings.text: The Custodian-General had jurisdiction under s.27 of the Act to revise and set aside the order of the Custodian dated August 22, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that considering the purpose for which the Act was passed and the successive saving clauses in the second Mysore Act and in the Act,,the Custodian General had the power under s. 27

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.27 confers wide revisional power over any proceeding/order by Custodian; prior state acts repealed/saved/deemed under central Act; purpose of uniform central administration of evacuee property.

holdings.text: No appeal lay to the High Court from the order of the Custodian dated December 2, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was in error in holding that appeals to it lay from the order of December 2, 1952.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substantive right of appeal under first Mysore Act s.30 taken away by necessary intendment of subsequent acts; proceedings deemed continued under new appeal provisions to Custodian-General.

holdings.text: Proceedings under s.8 of the first Mysore Act are in substance the same as under s.5 of the second Mysore Act and s.7 of the central Act.

anchor.surface_text: As we have pointed out above the proceedings under s. 8 of the first Mysore Act are in substance equal to proceedings under s. 5 of the second Mysore Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both involve inquiry/evidence to determine if property is evacuee property post-notification/notice; difference formal/procedural not substantial.

holdings.text: The right of appeal to the High Court conferred by s.30 of the first Mysore Act was taken away by necessary intendment of the subsequent legislation.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore to see whether it can be said that the right of appeal conferred by the first Mysore Act has been taken away by necessary intendment by the subsequent legislation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proceedings deemed under later acts via savings; legislature intended substitution of appeal forum to Custodian-General, not High Court; per Garikapatti precedent.

holdings.text: The High Court was not justified in interfering with the Custodian's order dated December 2, 1952 under Art.226 via writ of certiorari.

anchor.surface_text: In the view we have taken, the order of the Custodian-General was with jurisdiction and therefore there was in our opinion no reason for the High Court interfere in the exercise of its jurisdiction under Art. 226

holdings.reasoning_summary: No jurisdictional error, natural justice violation, or manifest error of law on face; certiorari supervisory, not appellate; per Hari Vishnu Kamath limits.

holdings.text: The second Mysore Act was repealed as from April 17, 1950 by the central Act via retrospective amendment of s.58.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear therefore that the second Mysore Act was expressly repealed as from April 17, 1950, by the Act in view of this substituted s. 58 put into it retrospectively by Act LXVI

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment Act LXVI retrospectively substituted s.58(2) explicitly repealing corresponding state laws from Act's commencement.

holdings.text: The appeals are allowed; High Court judgment set aside; Custodian's order of December 2, 1952 restored.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeals, set aside the order of the High Court and restore that of the Custodian dated December 2, 1952.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of holdings on jurisdiction, appeals, and writ limits.

anchor.surface_text: Garikapatti Veeraya v. Subbiah Choudhury 1 , where this Court held that the vested right of appeal was a substantive right and was governed by the law prevailing at the time of th companymencement of the suit and companyprised all successive rights of appeal from companyrt to companyrt which really companystituted one proceeding but added that such right companyld be taken away expressly or by necessary intendment.

precedents.cited_proposition: the vested right of appeal was a substantive right and was governed by the law prevailing at the time of the commencement of the suit and comprised all successive rights of appeal from court to court which really constituted one proceeding but such right could be taken away expressly or by necessary intendment

precedents.citation: Hari Vis Kamath v. Syed Ahmed Ishaque and others 2

anchor.surface_text: Hari Vis Kamath v. Syed Ahmed Ishaque and others 2  and the following four propositions were laid down Certiorari will be issued for companyrecting errors of jurisdiction Certiorari will also be, issued when the Court or Tribunal acts illegally in the exercise of its undoubted jurisdiction, as when it decides without giving an opportunity to the parties to be heard, or violates the principles of natural justice  3 , The companyrt issuing a writ of critorari acts in exercise of a supervisory land number appellate jurisdiction.

precedents.case_name: Hari Vishnu Kamath v. Syed Ahmed Ishaque and others
precedents.cited_proposition: limits of jurisdiction of High Court in issuing writs of certiorari: (1) correcting errors of jurisdiction; (2) illegal exercise of jurisdiction violating natural justice; (3) supervisory not appellate jurisdiction, no review of facts; (4) patent error of law apparent on face of record

anchor.surface_text: as pointed out in Hari Vishnu Kamaths case 2  it is number open on a writ praying for certiorari to review findings of fact reached by an inferior companyrt or tribunal even though they may be erroneous. Further, unless there is a patent error of law there can be numberinterference by a writ of certiorari.

precedents.cited_proposition: not open on certiorari to review findings of fact by inferior court or tribunal even if erroneous
